questions.text: Karyotyping of fetus can be done through all of the following invasive methods except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fetal skin biopsy is not a method for chromosomal analysis.
  • Currently there are 3 techniques available for obtaining fetal tissue for fetal karyotyping:
  • Chorionic villi sampling:(Option C ruled out)
    • Performed at 10-13 weeks. A catheter is passed through the cervix or through the abdominal wall into the uterus under ultrasound guidance, and a sample of chorionic villi surrounding the sac is obtained.
    • The chorionic villi are formed by trophoblast and hence study material is trophoblast.
    • In a morula the outer layer is trophoblast and inside is inner cell mass, So whatever chromosomal abnormalities are seen in the fetus can be detected by CVS.
  • Amniocentesis:(Option A ruled out)
    • It is an invasive procedure performed between 15 to 20 weeks for detecting fetal karyotype.
    • It is done under ultrasound guidance using a 22 gauge spinal needle. The spinal needle is passed through the mothers lower abdomen into the amniotic cavity inside the uterus and 10-20 ml of amniotic fluid is collected. Amniotic fluid has cells from amnion, fetal skin and lungs which are collected and cultured for fetal karyotyping, biochemical and metabolic analysis.
  • Percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS/Cordocentesis):(Option B ruled out)
    • The most frequent indication for cordocentesis is rapid karyotyping of the fetus (with PUBS-high quality karyotype can be obtained in 48-72 hours rather than in 10-14 days that is needed for amniotic cell culture).

questions.text: In following conditions, maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein values are increased except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) is associated with:
    • ↓ Decreased MSAFP
    • ↓ Estriol
    • ↑ hCG
    • ↑ Inhibin A (in quadruple screen)
  • Alpha Fetoprotein:
    • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a glycoprotein synthesized by the fetal yolk sac in early gestation and later by the fetal liver and gastrointestinal tract. It is the most abundant fetal serum protein. AFP levels rise in fetal serum until 13 weeks (up to ~3 mg/mL), then decline steadily throughout pregnancy. After birth, levels fall and reach adult levels (~1 ng/mL) by one year.
    • AFP circulates in fetal serum, is excreted in urine, and enters the amniotic fluid, from where it crosses into maternal serum via placental membranes and circulation. In open fetal defects (e.g., neural tube defects, abdominal wall defects), more AFP leaks into amniotic fluid, raising maternal serum AFP levels.Maternal screening is done between 15-20 weeks
  • Alpha fetoprotein will be increased in the following conditions.
    • Gastroschisis -Ventral abdominal wall defect(Option C ruled out)
    • Omphalocele- Ventral abdominal wall defect (Option B ruled out)
    • Spina bifida occulta -Neural tube defect (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Screening by using maternal serum alpha fetoproteins helps to detect all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Some conditions associated with abnormal maternal serum alpha fetoprotein concentration.
  • Elevated levels
    • Error in dates
    • Multifetal pregnancy
    • Severe oligohydramnios
    • Neural tube defects(Option A ruled out)
    • Pilonidal cysts
    • Esophageal or intestinal obstruction (and atresia)(Option B ruled out)
    • Liver necrosis
    • Cystic hygroma
    • Sacrococcygeal teratoma
    • Fetal death
    • Abdominal wall defects:
      • Omphalocele(Option D ruled out)
      • gastroschisis
    • Urinary obstruction
    • Renal anomalies:
      • polycystic kidney
      • absent kidneys
    • Congenital nephrosis
    • Osteogenesis imperfecta
    • Congenital skin defects
    • Cloacal exstrophy
    • Chorioangioma of placenta
    • Low birth weight
    • Placental abruption
    • Placenta accreta
    • Preeclampsia
    • Improper adjustment for low maternal weight
    • Maternal hepatoma or teratoma
  • Low level
    • G: Gestational trophoblastic diseases
    • O2: Overestimated gestational age, overweight mother
    • A: Spontaneous abortion
    • T: Trisomy (21 or 18)

choices.text: Diabetic patients have increased AFP level
MsAFP is unrelated to period of gestation

questions.text: About AFP true is :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Alpha fetoprotein:
    • It is glycoprotein produced by the fetal yolk sac and later by the liver.
    • The highest level of AFP in fetal serum and amniotic fluid is reached around 13 weeks and (3 mg/ml) thereafter it decreases.It is related to gestation.( Option C ruled out).
    • It is detected in maternal serum at 15-20 weeks of gestation.
    • Levels of alpha fetoprotein are decreased in Down's syndrome (Option D ruled out).
    • Normally MSAFP is lower in diabetic women but, if diabetic female carries a fetus with open NTD's alpha fetoprotein is increased (Option B ruled out).

questions.text: The best time to do chorionic villus sampling is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Biopsy of chorionic villi is typically performed between 10 and 13 weeks’ gestation.(Option A,B &C ruled out)
  • Advantages over amniocentesis:
    • The main advantage of CVS is that results are available earlier in pregnancy, which allows earlier and safer methods of pregnancy termination when results are abnormal.
  • Risks:
    • Chances of fetal loss/abortion 1-2% (more than amniocentesis).
    • If performed earlier than 9 weeks (typically around 7 weeks), increased chances of oromandibular limb hypogenesis and limb reduction defects.
    • It can cause rupture of membranes, leakage of amniotic fluid and infection.
    • Rh isoimmunization can occur in Rh-negative females.

questions.text: A 35-year-old G2P1 woman at 11 weeks of gestation presents for prenatal genetic diagnosis due to a previous child with a chromosomal disorder. She undergoes transcervical chorionic villus sampling (CVS) for early detection of chromosomal abnormalities. The procedure is uneventful, but she is counselled about rare complications associated with early CVS.Which of the following is a recognized fetal complication when CVS is performed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most common complication is CVS-increased chances of fetal loss or abortion.
  • The frequency of oromandibular limb hypogenesis however was increased after CVS when the procedure was performed before 9 weeks.

Explanation of other options:

  • Limb abnormality(Option A):CVS done before 10 weeks of gestation has been associated with a rare risk of transverse limb reduction defects and oromandibular hypogenesis.The risk is minimized if CVS is performed after 10 completed weeks.This is the unique fetal complication linked specifically with early CVS.
  • Spina bifida(option B): Spina bifida is a neural tube defect related to folate deficiency, maternal diabetes, or teratogens (e.g., valproate).CVS does not cause neural tube defects.
  • Down's syndrome(Option C): Down syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality that is detected by CVS, not caused by it. CVS is one of the diagnostic tests for chromosomal disorders.

questions.text: Early date for detection of fetal heart:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Embryonic investigations suggest that cardiac contractions begin in the fetus at 36 days gestational age.'
  • Cardiac activity should be detected routinely when the embryo attains a length of 4 to 5 mm. This corresponds to a GA of 6.0 to 6.5 weeks, at which time the MSD is 13 to 18 mm. (Option B,C and D ruled out)
  • Using a transabdominal approach, cardiac activity should be evident by 8 weeks GA, when the MSD is 25 mm.'

choices.text: Estimation of serum beta-hCG in urine

questions.text: Best confirmation for pregnancy at six weeks?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The transabdominal scanning, the gestational sac is reliably seen in the uterus by 6 weeks, and fetal echoes and cardiac activity by 7 weeks. With transvaginal scanning, these are seen about 1 week earlier, thus confirming pregnancy.

Explanation of other options:

  • Doppler (Option B): Confirmation of cardiac activity by Doppler can be done only at 10 weeks and not 6 weeks.
  • Estimation of serum beta-hCG in urine(Option C)The level of hCG is not the best confirmatory test for pregnancy as hCG in plasma and urine are strikingly increased in women with hydatidiform mole.
  • Bimanual palpation(Option D):Bimanual palpation can only detect uterine enlargement but the cause of uterine enlargement can only be detected by ultrasound.

questions.text: Pseudogestational sac seen in ultrasonography of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A pseudogestational sac is a fluid-filled structure that can appear in the uterus during early pregnancy but does not contain an embryo. It often resembles a true gestational sac on ultrasound, leading to confusion in diagnosis.
  • Pseudogestational sacs are typically associated with ectopic pregnancies or early pregnancy loss, indicating the absence of viable pregnancy. Proper assessment through additional imaging and clinical evaluation is essential for accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Which one of the following congenital malformations of the fetus can be diagnosed in the first trimester by ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Anencephaly can be diagnosed as early as 8-10 weeks/first trimester in experienced hands.
  • Microcephaly:(Option B and C ruled out)
    • It has decreased head size.
    • In these patients both brain mass and total cell number are reduced.
    • There is a disproportion in size between the skull and face.
    • It is difficult to recognize this anomaly by ultrasound: A head circumference below 2 SD from the mean is used as a diagnostic criteria in midtrimester scan.
  • Holoprosencephaly is the presence of a single centrally placed cerebral ventricle and may be associated with midline abnormalities of the face. With the use of a vaginal probe it can be recognised in the beginning of midtrimester.(Option D ruled out)

choices.text: Stomach and umbilical vein, perpendicular to spire

questions.text: During USG, fetal abdominal circumference is measured at the level of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The abdominal circumference is measured at a transverse plane (i.e plane perpendicular to fetal spine) at the level of stomach and conference of the umbilical vein with the portal sinus.
  • It is an indicator of fetal growth, hence is an indicator of IUGR/macrosomia in the fetus.
  • Biparietal diameter:- is measured in transthalamic view at the level of thalamic and cavum septum pellucidum (CSP), from the outer edge of the skull to inner edge of the distal skull.

questions.text: Best marker of gestational age in 2nd trimester is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ultrasonographic 'fetal measurements' commonly used are
    • T1- Crown Rump length
    • T2-
      • Biparietal diameter
      • Head circumference(Option B ruled out)
      • Abdominal circumference
      • Femur length
    • Best parameter for dating of pregnancy - Measurement of CRL in 1st trimester.
    • Most sensitive parameter for assessment of fetal growth is abdominal circumference
    • Best parameter for assessment of gestation age in the second trimester : Biparietal diameter

questions.text: On Doppler the most ominous sign indicating fetal compromise is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Umbilical artery doppler :Blood flow across the umbilical arteries provides a comprehensive overview of the fetal blood supply and helps in detecting fetal circulatory compromise
  • As gestation increases, there is gradual fall in all the resistance indices so the amount of forward diastolic flow increases (Remember: Diastolic flow is inversely related to peripheral resistance). Normally, systolic/diastolic rates decrease as the period of gestation increases.
  • If S/D ratio more than 3 beyond 28 wks is a marker of UPI / IUGR .
  • In IUGR, there are three abnormal flow patterns; reduced EDF, absent EDF and finally reversal of flow.
  • Absent end diastolic flow (AEDF): It is an indication of termination of pregnancy, if pregnancy > 34 weeks by cesarean section.
  • Reversed end diastolic flow (REDF).
    • It is an indication of termination of pregnancy after 32 weeks gestation age. Patients have to be closely monitored and observed for changes in ductus venosus flow. Umbilical artery velocimetry provides a useful adjunct in management of high risk pregnancy. They are however not recommended for screening low risk pregnancies
  • Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)
    • Doppler measurement of middle cerebral artery velocimetry has been studied and employed clinically for detection of fetal anemia.
    • With fetal anemia, the peak systolic velocity is increased (≥ 1.5 MOM) due to increased cardiac output and decreased blood viscosity. This has permitted the rhesus group alloimmunization.

MCA Doppler has also been studied as an adjunct to the evaluation of fetal-growth restriction. It is believed that there is a progression of Doppler findings in severely affected fetuses such that increased impedance of flow in the umbilical artery may be detected first. This is followed by redistribution of flow to the brain, with decreasing resistance that has been termed brain sparing, and eventually by abnormalities in venous flow

choices.text: Two fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 20 minutes
One fetal heart rate acceleration is noted in 20 minutes
Two fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 10 minutes
Three fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 30 minutes

questions.text: With reference to fetal heart rate, a nonstress test is considered reactive when:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Non Stress Test: It is the most commonly used test for antepartum evaluation of the fetal status.
  • Principle : The test looks for the presence of temporary accelerations of fetal heart rate (FHR) associated with fetal movement. Presence of spontaneous fetal heart rate acceleration associated with fetal movements is an indicator of fetal well being, likewise the absence of fetal reaction suggests the possibility of fetal hypoxia.
  • Interpretation: Reactive/Positive NST-2 or more accelerations of at least 15 beats per minute, each lasting for at least 15 seconds and occurring within 20 minutes of the beginning of the test.(Option B,C and D ruled out)
  • If the 20 minute test is not reactive, do a 20 minute repeat test to account for the fetal sleep cycle before concluding the test non reactive.
  • Reactive test means that the fetus is in no danger for at least 7 days.
  • Most common condition for nonreactive NST - fetal hypoxia.
  • Time for performing these test:
    • Testing should begin by 32 weeks
    • In pregnancies with severe complications, begin at 26-28 weeks.
  • In case test is being performed before 32 weeks, accelerations are defined as having 10 bpm or more above baseline for 10 seconds or longer:
  • Interval between NST testing
    • Ideally -repeated weekly
    • In high risk pregnancies like diabetes mellitus, IUGR and Gestational hypertension twice weekly

questions.text: 35 weeks pregnant diabetic female with NST non- reactive. What should be done next?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the case of a 35-week pregnant diabetic female with a non-reactive non-stress test (NST), the next step should be (D) proceed to biophysical profile. This helps further assess fetal well being before deciding on intervention.(Option A,B and C ruled out)
  • Biophysical Profile (BPP): This test combines an NST with an ultrasound assessment to evaluate several aspects of fetal health.
  • The BPP assesses:
    1. Fetal Heart Rate (NST component): Evaluates heart rate patterns.
    2. Fetal Breathing Movements: Checks for episodes of breathing.
    3. Fetal Movement: Assesses general body movements.
    4. Fetal Tone: Looks for muscle tone and flexion of the limbs.
    5. Amniotic Fluid Volume: Measures the amount of amniotic fluid.

questions.text: A G2P1L1, woman at 35 weeks of pregnancy complains of decreased fetal movement. Next step in Management is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In a woman at 35 weeks of pregnancy (AG2P) who complains of decreased fetal movement, the next step in management is to do NST (Non-Stress Test). This test helps assess fetal well-being by monitoring heart rate patterns in response to movement.(Option A,C and D ruled out)
  • If the NST is non-reactive, further evaluation such as a biophysical profile (BPP) may be considered.

questions.text: In a nondiabetic high risk pregnancy, the ideal time for non-stress test monitoring is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Intervals between NST testing

  • The interval between tests is arbitrarily set at 7 days.
  • According to ACOG, more frequent testing is advocated for women with post term pregnancy, type I diabetes mellitus, IUGR or gestational hypertension.
  • In these circumstances some investigators recommend twice weekly (i.e. after 72 hours) with additional testing performed for maternal or fetal deterioration regardless of the time elapsed since the last test.(Option A,C and D ruled out)
  • Generally daily NST is recommended with severe preeclampsia remote from term.

questions.text: Manning score includes/Biophysical score includes:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • These 5 variables together are called as Biophysical Profile (BPP)/Biophysical score
    • Fetal Tone
    • Fetal Breathing Movements (seen in 30 minutes)
    • Fetal gross body Movements (seen in 30 minutes)
    • Amniotic Fluid Volume
    • Non stress test

Fetal Biophysical Profile (BPP)

  • Biophysical profile is a screening test for uteroplacental insufficiency. The fetal biophysical activities are initiated, modulated and regulated by the fetal nervous system. The fetal CNS is very much sensitive to diminished oxygenation/ Hypoxia, Metabolic acidosis, CNS depression, Changes in fetal biophysical activity.
  • Indication of BPP scoring -Nonreactive NST'high risk pregnancy.
  • The variables are observed for at least 30 minutes and assigned a score of 2 each to normal variables and a score of 0 to abnormal variables.
  • Thus the highest score possible for a normal fetus is 10.
  • A score of 8 to 10 is normal, 6 is equivocal and 5 or less is abnormal.

BPP Scoring, interpretation and management

Predictive value of All variables is not same :

  • Most important variables are NST and Amniotic fluid volume.
  • Intermediary important: Fetal breathing movement.
  • Least important: Fetal tone and fetal body movement.

questions.text: Which is the most significant finding in cardiotocography for detection of fetal hypoxia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Late decelerations are smooth falls in the FHR beginning after the contractions have started and ending after the contractions have ended. They are associated with fetal hypoxemia and potential for perinatal morbidity and mortality.
  • Variable decelerations are abrupt in decline and return to baseline, vary in timing with the contractions, and usually represent cord compression.
  • Early deceleration on cardiotocography (CTG) is typically due to fetal head compression and is considered a normal physiological response during labor.
  • A sinusoidal pattern on CTG is an abnormal finding and is classically associated with fetal anemia and fetal heart failure.

questions.text: Banana and lemon sign is seen in which fetal anomalies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Signs of Spina bifida on Ultrasound

  • Frontal bone scalloping or the so-called lemon sign.
  • Elongation and downward displacement of the cerebellum-the so-called banana sign.
  • Effacement or obliteration of the cisterna magna.

choices.text: Determination of uterine size on pelvic examination
Crown rump length on abdominal or vaginal examination
Determination of progesterone level along with serum hCG level

questions.text: A patient presents for her first initial antenatal visit after performing a home pregnancy test and gives a last menstrual period of about 8 weeks ago. She says she is not entirely sure of her dates, however because she has a long history of irregular menses. Which of the following is the most accurate way of dating the pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most accurate way of dating the pregnancy in the first trimester would be : Crown rump length on abdominal or vaginal examination.
  • This method is more reliable than relying on the last menstrual period, especially in cases of irregular menstrual cycles.
  • Crown rump length provides a more precise estimation of gestational age based on the measurement from the top of the baby's head to its bottom.
  • Quantitative serum hCG confirms pregnancy and progesterone with hCG helps assess viability, but neither can accurately date gestation due to wide variability.(Option B and D ruled out)

questions.text: Appropriate material for antenatal diagnosis of genetic disorders includes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Maternal urine is not used for antenatal diagnosis of genetic disorders.
  • Prenatal genetic diagnosis can be made by the following methods:
    • Chorionic villus sampling: Involves obtaining placental chorionic villi (trophoblastic tissue) via transabdominal or transcervical route for early karyotyping or molecular analysis.(Option C ruled out)
    • Cordocentesis: Involves sampling fetal blood from the umbilical vein under ultrasound guidance. Useful for rapid karyotyping, fetal anemia evaluation, infections, and certain metabolic tests.(Option A ruled out)
    • Amniocentesis: Involves aspirating amniotic fluid (contains fetal cells) transabdominally under ultrasound guidance. Used for fetal karyotyping, enzyme analysis, DNA-based testing, etc.(Option B ruled out)
